---
title: Why code organization falls apart
slug: why-code-organization-falls-apart
description: none
readingTime: 10 min
category: Mobile web
date: '17. December 2020'
---

import Info from 'components/blog/info'

React is very unopinionated when it comes to structuring your code.
There were a few attempts at organization patterns (like the "presentational component & container" pattern) but they were quickly tossed aside.
Others, like filesystem routing stuck around and are taking over the entire ecosystem.

<Info>When I talk about code structure it includes everything from file structure to naming patterns. Anything that helps you organize your code.</Info>

We can summarize the concept in 1 word: **Ambiguity** _(or the lack thereof)_. In this article I'll explain what I mean by that and how you can use it to make better decisions when it comes to structuring your code and designing your apis.

I'll do it by examining some examples:

## Components - container pattern

This pattern suggests splitting components into 2 categories. "Containers" take care of all the application logic, data fetching etc.
"Presentation components" are pure components that only take care of "how things look".
Check the [full article](https://medium.com/@dan_abramov/smart-and-dumb-components-7ca2f9a7c7d0) to learn more about this pattern.

### Where it falls apart:

Let's say you need to build a "navlink". A navlink acts like a normal link but when its HREF matches the page URL we style it differently to show the user what page he's on.
Now if we follow our pattern dogmatically then we need to move that piece of state (active / inactive) to the parent container.
But now if we want to reuse our navlink component somewhere else we need to copy that logic to the other container as well.
So in the end you decide to just put the state in the navlink after all and put it into the container folder to keep proper code organization.
Some time later, a colleague is building a nav in another part of the application. He checks the components folder but there's no navlink here so creates his own.
Now your website has 2 navlinks.

The situation was **ambiguous**. You could justify making it a container but making it a component is just as logical.
Especially when time is short developers just don't have time for mental Gymnastics.

Let's contrast this to another popular code structure:

## Filesystem routing

This approach to routing is used in Next.js, Gatsby, Vue (nuxt.js) and the newly announced "Svelte kit". The way it works is simple, every file you create in the `pages` folder automatically gets turned into a route that matches the filepath

```
pages/
  ⊢ index.js // -> www.example.com/
  ⊢ about.js // -> www.example.com/about
  ⊢ user/
      ⊢ [userId].js // -> www.example.com/user/12345 (or any other id)
```

Technically pages are also just react components. The decision process here goes a bit like this:
